Goldilocks: The Board Game. It seems like once every blue moon I play the game Power Grid was intended to be, where nobody gouges the supply/demand economy (increasing the price for everyone reliant on the resource) but remains at the bottom of the lineup, and the map doesn't produce overcrowding at the start - effectively eliminating those players - while allowing backyard properties for others (prefer France, U.S. with Brown/Yellow/Red/Green, Benelux, mostly hate the rest), and some crap pull doesn't stagnate the power plant market, usually trash plants or low plants after a glut of high ones - and players sit around with little to do. (Especially bad if someone lucks into a 5-6 THEN the crap hits, more or less giving the game away.) Even the instances where those three elements coincide still seem problematic. Every game I can remember has always had a must-gamble-to-win situation; because players are always aiming for the best/highest plants, low ones accumulate near the bottom and sooner or later every replacement is gambling. There's also a fiddly dilemma where players are required to "know their roles" in order to play a good game, and if someone doesn't realize he or she should be the person pushing the enevelope when it comes to city expansion the game can balk while waiting for Stage 2. (Many times, nobody wants to actually trigger Stage 2 for fear of getting blocked in, and as money accumulates this fear only worsens.) Still probably the best gateway game ever, unless you think Settlers and Carcassonne actually qualify as games.

Economic game with heavy focus on math. Certainly not for everyone, but anybody that enjoys squeaking efficiency out of a system will like this game. Factories are balanced in such a way that which ones will be valuable vary from game to game, depending on which factories other players take. If you get a factory or two that uses resources nobody else is competing for, you can save a lot of money. Others will then, in turn, begin to buy into factories which use that resource, and so other factories will become more efficient as they get rid of their old ones. This creates a constantly changing economy in the game, shifting around other players' decisions. As such, this "economy" will be different every time you play the game.

GAMEPLAY
Power Grid is a procedural game where players bid for power plants; buy resources to spin up said plants; build power station locations to form a network; and make energy bucks. The game ends when a player builds their 17th station; the player able to power the most stations wins the game.

THOUGHTS
There’s a lot to like about Power Grid.
• The resource market is a compelling supply and demand model that forces you to consider (again) initiative and forecast what opponents will or won’t want.
• The networking is maybe not the most interesting in and of itself but the constant income calculations and planning are extremely crucial to doing well. Knowing how and where to cut off an opponent is likewise key, but you’re never truly trapped as you can pay to build “through” an opponent but for a hefty price.
• Next to the resource market, the victory condition is my other favorite part of PG. I love the fact that not only is the game clock player driven, but the winner is not determined by who crosses the finish line first or who has the most money but who can power the most stations. It feels both thematic and clever.
• Finally, the variability provided with the expansion maps and their unique twists is extremely cool.

As for the negatives, PG can be a real slog, especially when I’m staring into the third hour and have to once again go through all the phases. You could say that’s your group and that would be fair, but I’ve played this with many different people in different settings and, even in my 3P games, it’s longer than I want it to be. Part of this is due to the procedural nature and the admin that’s folded into that. PG has a lot of upkeep and a lot of little rules, meaning constant reminders are necessary. Not a big deal in a one-hour game but much more onerous in longer ones. A final thing adding to the length is how player initiative affects game play: PG disincentivizes players from getting out into the lead early as those later in turn order strike first in buying resources and building stations. They’re also rewarded when the Step 2 floodgate is broken.

While I was initially quite high on PG, each successive play has emphasized the aspects I don’t care for while those that I like recede into the background.

Power Grid is a game I have owned since 2013. When I first decided to start a game night, I asked a former co-worker for recommended games and Power Grid was on his list.

I have never done very well at Power Grid, and I usually come in close to last. I struggle to get my engine going early and I haven't yet figured out why. Part of the problem is that my plays of Power Grid are so infrequent that I have forgotten details of previous plays by the time it makes it to the table again. So I likely repeat some of my same mistakes every game. I honestly don't care enough to go read strategy guides in between sessions. I'm not that kind of gamer.

It seems that if you can get two cities powered early, then you are on the right track. I probably overbid on power plants during the first turn, which makes it hard to buy fuel and build new routes. I end up with payment from powering a single city while others are reaping more. There's a balance that I just haven't figured out. In the past I've complained about a runaway leader problem in Power Grid. In the half dozen plays of the game I've had so far, I don't know how you catch up to someone when they are bringing in more money that you every turn. They can outbid you for new plants, and they can build up their route more quickly than you can. Perhaps one tactic is to stockpile the resources they need to drive prices up, but then you are spending money on resources that just sit.

I recently looked at Power Grid on the shelf and thought about selling it. I know it is a good game, I just haven't had a ton of fun with it because I am terrible at it. Is it okay to dislike a game simply because you are really bad at it? I can imagine my friend Jon rephrasing this question: "Do you only like games if you win them?" In some cases, I think the answer is yes. Winning certain games is where I find the enjoyment from that game. But there are certainly others, like For Sale or Modern Art, where I have fun regardless of the outcome.

So in the end, I am still considering selling my copy of Power Grid. Though I will probably keep it around for nights where we have 6 at the table and want something with a bit more depth.

You bid on power plants, of which you can have three and which take either one of four types of fuel or none, and then you buy types of fuel from a dynamic market affected by demand, after which you pay to build connected power stations on a map, and finally spend the fuel to power them according to your plants' capacity. The player who can power the most stations at a fixed point will win. Turn order is manipulable by number of built stations.

Hopefully, this game will live on as one of the enduring legacies of this hobby. Power Grid has it all: hardcore crunch, evocation, the prospect of an arc, sometimes comebacks, an accessible skill floor and a pretty high skill ceiling. The randomness and rubberbanding mean that, even though the 'best' player will usually win, they still have to perform consistently to win by any significant margin. And the game gives room to different valences of skill. If you dominate decision-making in the auctions, you will do well. But if you master the timing and turn order, then you can fuck everything else up and still have a lot of control.
